comment: This has always been pretty meh for me. Hate me or love me, I just don't see the price tag matching up to this one. I might grab it in the future for regifting purposes but it doesn't stand out for me.

Demand and the attempts to keep up with it are really putting a hurting on the quality of this line. I still enjoy it and maybe I've just gotten 2 bottles in a row that are a little off. It is a single barrel product so it could very well be. I'm not gonna say anything negative yet. If the next bottle or 2 doesnt get back to the level I expect for level of difficulty it is to obtain at 55 bucks I will begin to drop my rating.
Very smooth. Very crisp bourbon.  If someone asked me what does bourbon taste like, this is the archetype.
Rich, smokey, and smooth. It's like sinking into a leather recliner with a cigar in hand, with burnt sugar on the nose and a very slight black cherry and vanilla finish.
Almost out already. Not enough per bottle...

02/07/20, barrel #731, Warehouse H, Rick# 16.
Decided to pull the trigger on this based off reviews and exclusivity. Scored the last bottle too. Hard to get around me. 

Neat: Nose contained a bready essence which gave way to citrus, maple, and spice. Palate had a decent burn. Once numbed, I detected dominant notes of oak and leather. Cherry on the finish. Opening more nutmeg and/or baking spice emerged. 

Ice block: Removed the burn. Muted the fruit and maple somewhat. Thick oily mouthfeel. Subtle oak and leather. Makes it way easier to drink and forget the Abv which can catch up quick if not careful.
Light caramel on the nose. Bold flavor with mild heat, great mouthfeel. Very light lingering flavor on the palette.
This is delicious. Wish it wasn't so hard to find.
One of my favorites, sweet and smooth with hints of vanilla and caramel.

So this is a store pick but they're all single barrels and my experience tells me they are all over the map too so I'd not be too worried about this vs a normal pick.

Nose - Spiced apples, saw dust...it's really gives me a bit of an apple juice with a touch of cinnamon and maybe just being in a barn while nosing it. Relatively dry and not high on sweet notes, much more balanced than bourbon tends to be. I'm not getting the big vanilla or caramels of a more traditional bourbon. I do get corn.

Taste - A bit of spice, a then a very evenly balanced oak and sweet and earthy profile, which fades into corn bread. There's a drop or two of vanilla. Mostly oak, earthy, corn, more corn, and then some sweet notes here and there. I'm not sure where this one went wrong, but this is pretty below average bourbon. I'd say this is a poor bottle but my recent blanton's bottles have mostly been a bit disappointing. Plenty of alcohol on this one too which at 46.5 seems jarringly out of place. 

I hate to say this, but a part of me just realizes I've moved past Blanton's being a good bourbon to me. I am tasting flaws and imperfections that should have disqualified these barrels from being picked but due to mass production, younger barrels, and the reality that these were never that good, this one was enough better than side by side barrels a store picked it. 

Throwing a couple rocks in for the fun of it. This is after all how most people will drink blantons. Actually, it tastes more like a standard bourbon iced, still nothing special. 

Anyway, I've always felt blanton's was an over priced bourbon, but I used to feel it was still providing a bit of a premium experience. I have to admit, I really do think the bottle was a part of that even back when I started. There is something about mash bill 2 that is perhaps not my preferred choice, but I love small batch EH Taylor for the money.

Anyway 1.5 for me today. I think this is a below average whisky and I'm getting notes that make me debate going lower. It is frankly not that pleasant beyond that nice nose.
Vanilla And caramel up front followed by brown sugar/ baking spices and a strong orange hidden underneath it all

The second N
2-25-20, barrel no. 186, H, 7, bottle 241

Finally stumbled across this in the wild(I was shocked to see it) at specs while searching for Laphroaig Lore. Im a drinker not a collector so cracked it right open to see what all the fuss is about. Poured neat, nose is....well its pretty subdued. I like the descriptor of refined as it truly nails it. There is some honey graham cracker, butterscotch, soft gentle oak, light mandarin orange and plum skins all fluttering around with ZERO trace of ethanol. Time and a drop will no doubt bring out more nuance. First sip is so smooth and delicate you need to focus to pull the flavors out. Seriously this is so easy to drink while simultaneously delivering complex bourbon flavors without even a hint of ethanol explains why everyone raves about this. People who cannot handle high proof, beginners who only seek smoothness as well as seasoned drinkers will all find happiness here. Palate is runny caramel and seasoned oak with some nutmeg/allspice baking flare. Not much rye coming through but no matter. There is oiled catchers mitt, melted butter and cashew nuttiness with hint of dust on the back end . Finish is long salted oak, nut butter and caramel /butterscotch fading just a bit dry with cigar leaf and black tea. I think its fantastic and overrated at the same time. I appreciate the exquisite experience this offers yet I don't think it deserves the absolute adoration it receives. It is so hard to find and the price gouging has just added to the mystique. Do I think its excellent bourbon? Yes it is but by no means should you pay ridiculous $$ for it........95/100.........I paid $57 and at that price by all means grab it. Ive seen it going for $100 plus and would have to pass at that level. Imo Bookers,OF120, Stagg Jr all surpass it but that could just be my preference for high proof bold flavors
Rich and full, slightly sweet and smoky. Smoother than smooth
Probably a bit too spicy for my taste
This is the first whiskey I actually liked, and so starts the journey

Always such a great pour, very light, sweet, and delicate. 
Although mine is a barrel pick, it is like candy, with hints of hay, tons of butterscotch.

(Purchased a 350ml for the price listed) I’m again not blown away from the hype machine that is Buffalo Trace. Yea they make world class juice, but this single barrel isn’t mind blowing. Glad I purchased the mini because I still would prefer a handful of other whiskies you can purchase regularly. As far as tasting notes, it tastes like bourbon. Oak spice, not that sweet, not too far off from EHT small batch.
Vanilla, caramel, sweet and smooth!! Fantastic Bourbon!!!
smooth and easy. faint notes of syrup
It's everything you've ever heard about it, and more. Outstanding bourbon!
Absolutely exceptional. Beautifully oaky with vanilla and orange up front.  Maple, cinnamon, and smoke to finish.
For the price, I’d go with Legent or Buffalo Trace.

Color: Amber brown

Nose: Rye, musty corn, vanilla, oak, baking spice, hint of maraschino cherries and fruits

Palate: Sweet corn, oak, rye and the spice that come with it, oily

Finish: Easy short finish with soft oak notes and a dash of spice

This dram definitely shows it’s refined age on the Buffalo Trace mash bill. It is certainly enjoyable with rich sweet corn and rye notes. I can see the allure Blanton’s presents but, not the price tag. If you can find a bottle around MSRP or a pour between $9- $15 I say go for it.
Great bourbon, I get lots of clove flavor. Nice and smooth, only wish I could find it easier and a bit cheaper.

Subtle fruits on the nose - cherry, green apple and orange. After letting rest I get some slight vanilla and burnt sugar, creme brule comes to mind. Hints of tobacco. 

Very smooth initially with slight heat and bitterness covering the tongue on the back end. Hint of cherry. 


Good buy @ MSRP? All day long.
Good buy @ secondary prices? Not a chance.

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect

Nice hug, vanilla and caramel on the nose, real smooth, not too hot, more caramel, some citrus, some leather, medium finish with some spice and heat but not overpowering. On the whole, very balanced and delicious.
Almost all the way through John Wick 3 and I’ve been waiting to pour this until he has one. No more waiting.
Not insanely complex but what it does, it does very well. Very drinkable and cozy. After a few sips you really get this Golden Grahams and nutmeg flavor that is addicting.
Marshmallow with a lot of spice on the back end.
Interesting bourbon, oily and spicy while still maintaining that classic vanilla and caramel/toffee flavor!

I’m going to go on record and say that Michters is my baby. I love Michters. However, I will knock down a wall and make a separate room for my adopted child Blantons. I will give him the love and care he needs. You need to love all of your children the same, but there are days...
Cool finish when iced, but a tad too spicy for my palette
Delicious! I get a strong citrus, sweet taste. Very smooth, delightful sipping 🥃

Nose =  Nougat, Vanilla & Honey. Simply delightful. 
Palate = Sweet, Vanilla, Caramel. No heavy finish at all. 

A really nice experience. Blantons has a lot of hype around it.. I wouldn’t say it’s life-changing but it’s a really good one!
Super smooth vanilla, baking spice, incredible finish. Muy bueno.
Super smooth vanilla, baking spice, incredible finish. Muy bueno.
I definitely like it, it’s not the end all, but I enjoy it!! Vanilla and caramel tastes. Slight orange.

This is the bourbon that converts non-bourbon drinkers. Every time I introduce Blanton’s to someone they become obsessed. Smooth and subtle with lots of delicious notes. You see this bottle you need to buy it.

A quick impression here. I've had this many times and it's  my fav BT expression. 

The taste profile is rich & viscous, near oily. It's not a sweet whiskey, but there are sweet elements. This has a nicely complex profile with vanilla, caramel, dark cacao, hazelnut, and a slightly citrus finish. Nice barrel presence.

There's a nice warmth and a pepper note that has a slow fade. The better part of this bourbon is the finish. 

This is a fine $50 - $60 whiskey. At $65 I likely won't buy again. IMHO it's not really competitive at $75+.

Drink the whiskey,  not the hype.
Believe the Hype, such a well rounded Bourbon. Oak, Vanilla, Cherry, Apple, Caramel.
A great all around Bourbon. Smooth and flavorful.  A little bit of heat with notes of vanilla, caramel, and a slight hint of tobacco. A must have for any bourbon enthusiast.
Great taste with some heat. As it’s become more difficult to find, I’ve been trying to find the best ways to enjoy it. Cut the heat with a few drops of water or a side of a sugary drink.
Smooth. Smoooooooooth. Happy I have a bottle now!

Nose is just right with toffee, caramel, some oak and citrus.

Palate has a nice oily toffee along with traditional caramel and vanilla taste.

Finish has the oak, a hint of tobacco, and orange peel.

Overall it’s enjoyable and a great starter bourbon.
Light notes of caramel and orange. Very smooth and easy on the pallet. A little lingering spice.
Sweet, seems a bit like cherry/caramel to me, with a short but sweet finish. Drinking this after Russell’s reserve. Maybe not worth the price, but tastes like a sweeter, richer ER to me

Nose: Vanilla, caramel, orange
Neat: Same as nose with some chocolate 
Rocks: Vanilla and orange

Nose - Caramel and vanilla.
Palate - Molasses sweetness. Slight tongue burn.
A drop or two of water unlocks some great flavours.

Nose: caramel and spun sugar. Sweeter than a lot of others
Palate: burn on the front, thick bodied. Orange, caramel, and vanilla come through strong
Finish: mild burn, vanilla lingers

I smell vanilla, caramel and toffee on the nose and I taste chocolate orange on the tongue. The finish is medium that does leave a satisfactory feeling. It’s overall a nice bourbon for $50-60 range and I unsure if that justifies the hype and the huge demand. The bottle looks very pretty but I would rather have the Blantons gold than the original.
The master tasters notes are spot on, but with a strong spicy burning finish.
Stories are true. It’s delicious. Don’t expect the world’s greatest bourbon but goes down so easily. Plus there’s a phenomenal behind this bourbon. Fun and delicious experience.

The flavor is bitter off the bat with some sweetness and remarkable smoothness. I taste wood with a little iodine, red fruit, some walnuts, and a hint of toffee. The bitter notes fade, giving way to a sweet, creamy, and smooth finish. This is a bourbon that I would be happy to sip. The smoothness is really a wonder. This didn't quite knock my socks off, but I quickly realized that I liked it and wanted more. It tastes like it has low rye content, which makes me quite happy.
Rich and surprisingly smooth. There may be some mineral notes here, but there is also plenty of vanilla and toffee with s backing of woody age. This bourbon has a flavor that immediately leaps out as being well-developed and is immensely enjoyable.
It's smooth with some rich woodiness and not too much spice. It's a bit oily, but that mixes nicely with the vanilla, bits of rye tartness, and toffee. It isn't very sweet, but it is very balanced.
This is rich with coffee and toffee. There is not too much spice and the proof is just about right for a drink that is not trying to be cask strength. The balance is exquisite and it does not even need to rely upon high alcohol content to round it out. There are a lot of dimensions here and although they are sometimes muddled, the net result is usually terrific. Each flavor is good and the drink is enjoyable sweet despite its rich backing. I could throw nits at it or I could just say.that it's a delight to drink. This is less rich but arguably more complex than Delord 1981, making it quite a success and a testement that drinks can taste entirely different while being the same in quality.
The nose has mellow wood and chocolate with some harvest fruit. It smells smooth. The palate has some spice, but to is predominantly smooth and rich. You can taste the age here and the complexity gradually builds. There is plenty going on with chocolate, wood, toffee, just enough rye to add interest and make it a little mouth-watering, some hints of apple and cherry, vanilla, cinnamon, tiny bits of nutmeg, kind of a reference to clove, the faintest hint of allspice, and just the right amount of char. This is a masterful bourbon that sets a standard for others to strive for.
Actually, Blanton's tastes like an Armagnac or maybe even a Cognac in comparison to Booker's Kitchen Table. Blanton's tastes relatively weak due to its lower ABV, but its richness and age do start to show, letting it make the case for its quality. The smokiness in Blanton's gives it a mature character, but doesn't balance as well as Booker's does. It's hard to drink Blanton's after Booker's. Russell's Reserve Single Barrel has more of a punch and some nice woody spice mixed with its cherry flavor and strong vanilla than Blanton's does, so its distinct flavors might allow it to be more generally enjoyable, but Blanton's might be more subtle.

Nose: Chewy toffee and caramel. Like one of those chews that you get at a parade. Sweeter and more candy nose than other bourbons. Also, no cherry nose like I find with Eagle rare which is a happy find. Vanilla present as well. A little more complexity found if I swirl and take a deeper whiff. 

Taste: Smooth and very little burn. Most likely due to the 80 proof that is bourbon. Usually drink scotch. Not a lot of complexity. Just a great example of what to expect with a pure bourbon. Slightly oily but insignificant compared to an Islay scotch. 

Finish: Nothing substantial that is inconsistent with the initial taste. This whiskey gets it’s rave and appeal because it’s smooth, true to the bourbon style, and has a good marketing/bottling approach. Worth the $60 retail but not something to chase at absurd prices like some whiskey groups sometimes hype. Would maybe consider paying up to $100 if you are a true fan of bourbon and have never had it. Near the best I have but remember, bourbon is so restrictive that very little difference exists among products.
Everything just tastes like vanilla to me right now, so...
A perfectly balanced, nuanced, and oaky bourbon.
Spice early, sweet smooth but longer finish. Great for the right price
Honey color.  Spicy, caramel, and vanilla flavors.  Thicker mouth feel
On the nose vanilla with orange peel and some burnt sugar, on the taste some light spice and burnt sugar, Carmel finish.

I think that this is probably the best bourbon to give as a gift. Everything about it is warm and inviting, but fails to polarize or create a divisive opinion. Certainty not a bad trait! But if you’re looking for an interesting whisky, this is not it. 
On the nose sweet caramel and soft vanilla ride over the bing cherry and strawberry sweetness. The palate enforces the nose with reckless abandon without adding much barrel spice. The finish is rich and long and always invites another sip.

2nd time review 

Nose - vanilla, caramel, honey, very sweet nose and some leather and heat. 

Taste - this bourbon tastes just about how it smells which isn’t always the case. Very rich full and oily to begin. Starts sweet with the vanilla and caramel and maybe some honey. Finish is leather and a spice with some slight tongue burn in what I would describe as a medium long finish. 

Overall and value - I honestly love this bourbon. It’s great and best way to describe it is smooth and complex. For the 50-60$ price point and a very cool story, bottle, and topper you cannot go wrong. Paying secondary I would be a bit underwhelmed. I do hate how hard this bourbon is to find but it is very good.

While not my favorite, a VERY enjoyable and consistent pour.  
-Cheers
